respStmt.name: Simona Stoyanova
respStmt.resp: standardisation of template and tidying up encoding

availability.licence: Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.

support.p: A large fragment of a thick slab of compact grey limestone, with veins and crystalline structure. The slab is intact on the left and at the top. The upper left corner is broken, and the face along the upper edge has suffered some chipping and damage.The stone is broken off below and to the right. The preserved top and left sides have straight but only roughly chiselled finish. The face has been polished smooth. It is possible that the damage / hole in the left end of the top side is a damaged clamp hole. The rear is uneven and only very roughly worked, but never to a flat face, excpet perhaps for a narrow margin down the intact left rear edge and along the top rear. Two modern brackets for hanging the stone on a wall have been fixed to the rear face at some time since original discovery, by drilling screws into the rear face. The stone was originally wider than 43 cm (the total maximum preserved width), but the widest part of the surviving face is only 40cm.

layout.p: The text fills the face of the stone, with a margin of 10mm on the left edge, and a margin along the top of 22mm. The first two lines are larger than the rest.

handNote.p: Types list: Α type1 Α type1.3 Α type2 Β type2 Β type2.2 Ε type2 Ε type2.3 Ε type2.3.1 Ε type2.3.2 Θ type1 Θ type1.2 Κ type1 Κ type1.1 Μ type3 Μ type3.1 Μ type3.2 Ν type2 Ν type2.2 Ο type1 Ο type1.2 Π type2 Π type2.1 Π type2.2 Ρ type1 Ρ type1.1 Ρ type1.3 Σ tyoe3.2 Σ type3 Σ type3.1 Τ type2 Τ type2.1 Υ type2 Υ type2.1 Φ type2 Φ type2.2 Ω type2 Ω type2.2 Ω type2.2.1

origin.origDate: Second or earlier first century BCE, primarily on palaeographic grounds (Manganaro various proposed dates between the end of 2nd century BCE and end of 1st century BCE (Manganaro 1963 and Cebeillac Gervasoni suggest post 36 BCE, assuming that line 17 implies the status of Centuripe as Latin municipium, which seems doubtful); Dubois, IGDS, suggests early 2nd century).

history.provenance: Said originally to be found at the locality of Acquamara, but seems likely to have come from the area thought to be that of the anicent agora / forum, slightly north of the location of the so-called Augustalia. The piece was found by a private individual in 1962, and passed into private hands. It is now in the custody of the Soprintendenza per i Beni Culturali e Ambientali di Catania, and temporarily on display at the Centuripe museum (September 2024).37.62281,14.7405836
Prag 2024-09-27 in the Museo Archeologico Regionale di Centuripe

app.note: Text based upon autopsy, without attempting extensive reconstruction; number of letters in the lacunae in the left margin based upon measurements.
The final letter has the angle of omega and can only be read as omicron with difficulty.
There is the possible trace of a letter top at the very base of the stone.

div.p: [after the edition of Cebeillac-Gervasoni] The ambassadors who went to Rome and to Lanuvium, according to the instructions which they had received, Philarchos, son of Philarchos, Lamp[---, son of ---], and Xoarchos, son of Meniskos, report that they went to Lanuvium and that they have renewed links of hospitality and of kinship between the people of Centuripe and the people of Lanuvium, and that they bring a decree from the senate of the Lanuvians: Furius, son of Publius, the dictator, and Gaios Atellios son of [---] and [---] son of Gaios, the aediles, convened the senate [---] days before the Kalends of December. The decree was composed by Leukios son of [---], Markios son of Quintus, and Leukios Kaptios, son of Markos. Concerning those matters about which Philiarchos, son of Philiarchos, Lamp[-- son of ---] and Xoarchos, son of Meniskos, ambassadors of the Kentoripini [---?---] of the people and the senate of the Kentoripini [---?---], in order to renew the links of hospitality and of kinship and [---?---] for their descendants, as a memorial [---?---] just as the ambassadors, fine and noble men, have renewed [---?---] have received [---?---] the colony (apoikia) of the Kentoripini [---?---].
